reviewText: This is not at all what I was expecting.  I thought it would be more like Desert Strike on the SNES/PS.  Controls and gameplay were not very enjoyable.  Graphics settings also didn't stick so it was playing at an extremely low resolution.\n\nIt's a rail based shooter that you control the speed at which you advance, but don't the ability to stop and shoot, or aim very well at a particular target.  Not to be snide, but arcade games 15 years ago played a lot better, and looked better.

reviewText: This is easily one of the saddest games I've ever played.  Not sad as in gripping story"

column16: a poor grasp of the english language
column18: or all three.  In addition to the pre-mission text
column19: the same actor also shouts out random "taunts" and "reactions" as you play.  I put those in quotes because they are all delivered with all the emotion of a plank of wood.  Not only that
column20: the random barks are translated just as badly as the main text
column21: leaving us with taunts like "take that terrorist dog".  There's very little variety
column23: so get used to hearing "see you later alligator" delivered by a heavily tranquilized teenage mental patient a million times.\n\nAs for actual gameplay
column24: it's pretty bad.  Your main weapons is your basic gattling gun
column25: though it seems to cut out randomly; I'm unsure if its because of poor control implementation or some sort of overheat system that isn't displayed on screen.  You have two banks of missiles you can choose from
column26: but they do barely any more damage than the gattling guns
column27: and the difference between the two is not obvious and is definitely not explained.  In fact very little in this game is explained other than "shoot things and sometimes it extends your time".  Random pickups float in the world
column28: corresponding to mechanics that you can only guess at based on their icons.  Picking up these items results in bright
column29: flashy effects that signify seemingly nothing
column30: and half the time you can't even pick them up for reasons which (again) aren't explained.  You weapons do a varying amount of damage
column32: sometimes mowing down enemies in quick succession
column33: sometimes taking 2-5 seconds just to take down a basic grunt.  Targeting is entirely automatic and picks up far too slowly
column34: leaving you with no way to dumbfire at enemies you know will be coming from the top of the screen.\n\nBeyond the gameplay though
column35: the rest of the game is pretty annoying too.  The menu screen is a constantly revolving and zooming view of a helicopter
column36: set at a speed juuuuuust fast enough to make you slighty queasy.  The configuration options are confusing
column37: using non-standard button names for gamepads
column38: particularly 360/XBO controllers which should have native Windows support
column39: though to be fair the options are rather detailed within that.  The biggest problem though is that you are required to enter your serial key for the game literally every time you start it
column40: and sometimes randomly when you back out of a sub-menu.  On my first launch I started the game
column43: then was prompted to enter my serial key AGAIN.  Oh
column45: it refused to accept my serial key the second time.  I wound up having to restart the game entirely.\n\nIn short
column46: Heli Heroes is a hot mess. There's some basic enjoyment to be found under there
column47: but the overall system is too clunky and confusing to make that an easy task.  You may need to consume a great quantity of alcohol to find this game not annoying
column48: and even then who knows.  Quite honestly you will find a more robust and rewarding helicopter game in something like Tiger-Heli for the original NES
column49: because at least that has consistent controls
column51: and no repeated requests for a serial key.  Do not waste your money or time on this game."

reviewText: I love me some arcade shooters, in all their campy gloriousness, but this one was not fun for me.  I'm pretty forgiving of this genre, but this one has some flaws that annoyed the crap out of me.  It has terrible overused one-liners and non-intuitive level navigation.  I'm ok with one-liners, but when you have one for EVERY single defeated enemy, and random map desstructible, then it gets really old.  Especially when you light up a grove of trees, and then you hear, Die terrorists!" and 9 other equally engrossing one liners. Even some of the training levels were tough to navigate.  One such level required that you defeat all enemies
date: but took me about 30 minutes of trial and error to reach some obscure corner to destroy some benign weapons cache to win.  Overall
hoursPlayed: but gameplay has some flaws.  If they fixed these quirks I'd say it still remains a mediocre shooter."

reviewText:
This is a game I, almost sad to say, looked forward to. It looked decent enough and it was only a couple of bucks (I bought it on sale, by the way). What I got was a rather clunky experience that I only enjoyed with a friend, but not alone. I'll list out my problems below:

Controls: For the most part, the controls responded to my inputs. For some reason, my controls gave out on the third tutorial. It seems as though control of your helicopter freaks out sporadically. However, those times are few and far between, so the controls are alright at best in my opinion.

Game Play: Lackluster. There is no real sense of where you're supposed to aim at the enemies and overall it seems like the one thing I look for in a game, bores me to death. Also, the helicopters you get to chooses from don't even feel different in the slightest.

Powerups: I add this because when an arcade game comes along, there is bound to be powerups found. However, most of the time, I don't know what they do. Some are self-explanitory, but other don't make any sense. If there was a system that told me or at least some kind of instruction, I would be fine with it.

Voice Acting: This is one part of the game I like solely for the reason it sounds like early PS1 english voice dubbing.

Soundtrack: Forgettable. Sometimes non-exsistent.

3/10. This game is a lackluster experience unless you have a friend along. If this was a comepletely single-player experience, it would score lower. All in all, do NOT buy this game.

reviewText:
I wated to like this game, I really did. I have a soft spot in my heart for these mindless shmups, a nice way to unwind instead of playing something that taxes your brain. Graphics are good for release date (2002, at least they're honest about it), but the physics leave something to be desired - your chopper often clips through terrain, and why you can't change height is beyond me. But there's one thing that killed my enjoyment of the game..

The voiceover.

The voiceover when you destroy an enemy, take a hit, grab a powerup.... just awful. Immediately breaks any kind of immersion or concentration. God-awful.

Pass unless you get as part of a bundle, then mute it and enjoy a couple of minutes.

reviewText:
Heli Heroes is a budget title from early 2000s and a vertical shump at that. It doesn't seem to be much, but genres like this one were already viewed as a thing of a past by that time. I could easily mistake it for a Shareware game, expect it isn't.

As it's quite an old game, how does it work? Well... one thing for sure is that it works. You can configure the game, where you can set a resolution. But while you can choose widescreen resolution out of a list, a game wasn't designed for this. What it will do is to cut a portion of screen above and below, so in order to see whole intented game screen, you should set resolution to 4:3 one!
You also can't change controls, and seeing how it uses Shift and Ctrl, you better be careful at button mashing it, unless you want curious Windows to interrupt you. Just hold it carefully.
And yes, the pleasent thing of having to enter your key and of having score leaderboards not work anymore.

At the main menu you can choose whetever you want to Start Game or want do Competition. Competition is like a classic arcade game, or like endurance, or survival... Anyway, you have to play from first mission without continues and saving of sorts, and your score will be written down in highscore leaderboard where you compete with other players for better score if forget that it doesn't work anymore.
Otherwise, you head into simple Start Game, where you can choose mission and difficulty, the missions being unlocked progressively. And you can choose between two helicopters, first one having guy as voice and has more damaging chaingun, while second has female as pilot and has more armor. You probably should go with first one, but then again, you will spam rockets a lot more. Male voice is also more tolerable, and characters speak a lot in this game, somewhat cool and somewhat annoyingly. Yelling to find ejection button upon single hit and saying take that you terrorist dog" upon shooting down a tree.
And then there is a two-player cooperative mode. But it's a local thing only
date: hope you got a friend who doesn't mind trying games like this. Didn't get to try it myself. But you can also easily control two players in same time on keyboard
recommended: if you want to try something new for fun.\n\nThe story is quite simple. You are American. And then there is America's dream enemy
hoursPlayed: the terroristical group Revolution Now. NOW!! Which has both arabian and russian roots
voteText: as well as a bit of alien.\nOn good side

votesTotal: 2000 year lighting looks jolly on the nighty Siberia levels. And yes
votesFunny: it's one of better moments in game
commentsCount: while you listen to the better music out of a very small selection that game has.\n\nSo yes

column25: in which you had to choose what turn to take every few seconds or so
column28: you make things explode. You collect power-ups to level up your minigun
column30: as it heats up and starts to shoot slower. And you collect all kinds of rockets
column31: whetever lasers or big nuclear bomb
column32: which is hard not to take damage from
column33: and spam it on everything as well.\n\nOh

column40: maybe too quickly. Weird concept.\n\nSo yes. It's not horrible. It's a small budget game from 2000s. Doesn't bring anything new

reviewText: I had my hopes up when I saw this title for a bargain. It gave me a flashback of old classic top-down scrollers that I used to play with my friends as a kid. And this game seemed to have 3D graphics instead of bitmaps -- which in some cases does work out.\n\nWith anticipation rising I launched the game, checked the controls and started my flight. The pad controls felt suitable and the chopper felt to respond rather well. First target in sight! Fire! ... Die
recommended: so the ammo automatically hits the target if you are remotely aiming towards it
hoursPlayed: I can live with that. And I could even live with below mediocre level design and cloggy textures and below average sound effects. But I cannot tolerate those darn pilot comments every time a target is taken out or you are getting hit! Sure
voteText: there's a variety in those but that's pretty much all you hear along side with poorly suiting sound track.\n\nFour training missions was enough for me. There are better games to spend your time with than this. There is a 2 player co-op but I rather have a friend join me for a game of Rayman than Heli Heroes. There's nothing heroic in this game."
